Hector.Action: Calls out to his son to go back home and leave him alone, demonstrating awareness of his surroundings and control over the situation.
Plays roughly with his children, acting as a trapped wild animal; however, he loses control and throws his son too hard causing injury.
Kneels beside his daughter and is deeply absorbed in her dreamlike antics, showing emotional engagement and observational skill.
Rejects his son’s desire to accompany him for foraging, repeatedly telling him to stay away with visible anger.
Shows frustration and recognizes he is in a no-win situation as his wife offers comfort to their rejected son.
Smiles while observing seabirds, showing connection to his environment and acceptance of natural cycles.
Feels fear and acts to protect his family by rushing back to the cave upon seeing a threat approaching.
Surveys his environment calmly, recognizes natural patterns and his place within the ecosystem.
Notices smoke and immediately takes action by running to a vantage point to assess threat.
Strains his eyes to detect danger and accurately identifies the approaching boats as a menace.
Runs toward safety upon recognizing the threat, demonstrating quick decision-making under fear.
Exhibits blind, gut-turning fear which might impair rational response.
Watches his family being taken away with evident pain and retreats into darkness to avoid confronting the painful reality
Observes the Raiders' camp from a hidden vantage point, assessing the situation calmly.
Does not attempt to intervene or communicate with his family or the Raiders despite the emotional pain he feels.
Recognizes and accepts the harsh reality of his family's abduction and the limited options available to him.
Retreats quietly into the hills after observing the scene instead of confronting or seeking help immediately.
Screams agonizingly at the Raiders and throws stones at them in a mad, desperate attempt to stop their departure, showing his emotional vulnerability and protective instincts toward his family.
Watches his family silently as they board the boats, noting their fear and restrained emotions, indicating a deep awareness and empathy for their situation.
Retreats alone into darkness and endures a long cold night without comfort or solace, showing internal suffering but no outward hostile behavior.
Returns the Raiders' fierce looks and endures their mocking laughter without escalating conflict, demonstrating resilience but also a lack of direct friendly engagement.
Remains passive and does not resist when captured, despite the fear and tension, allowing Deirdre to hold back their children from defending him.
Is confused and unsure how to respond to the Leader's provocations and questions, showing a vulnerable and sincere reaction rather than hostility or aggression.
Shows confusion and does not understand the situation or the Leader's questions, remaining passive despite being bound and confronted.
Does not resist when the Raiders seize him and bind his hands, allowing himself to be taken without struggle.
His family is fearful but he remains stoic, though without taking initiative or action.
Sits quietly, shows no aggression despite being rejected and possibly left for dead.
Attempts to follow the group after they reject him, indicating a desire to stay connected despite exclusion.
Does not retaliate or respond with hostility when told 'Off you go. We don't want you.'
Sits quietly, shocked and unable to react meaningfully when the group decides not to throw him off the cliff.
Attempts to unpick the rope that binds his hands when left alone.
Attempts to catch up and follow the group after they leave him.
Dumbly tags along behind the Raiders despite being rejected and treated as an embarrassment.
Refuses the cut piece of rope offered by the Raider as a gesture of conciliation.
Stands attentively, alert to any hint of need from his master, showing focus and readiness.
Moves immediately to assist his master with the towel as soon as he climbs out of the pool.
Follows his master's anxious movements through the bathhouse and shows concern, indicating emotional awareness and loyalty.
Produces a small wooden stool quickly and quietly to assist his master, demonstrating preparedness and resourcefulness.
Produces a small wooden stool for his master to sit on as he joins others.
Moves out of earshot but remains alert to his master's behavior, sharing in his master's feelings of discomfort though powerless.
Quickly stands by Lucinnius's side when the three men show contempt and make a sarcastic remark.
Follows closely behind Lucinnius carrying all his belongings, showing loyalty and care.
Produces a small wooden stool promptly and serves his master attentively.
Moves out of earshot but remains alert to his master's behavior, showing situational awareness.
Quickly stands by Lucinnius's side as they leave after a sarcastic remark, showing loyalty and readiness.
Carries multiple items for his master (towel, scrubber, robe, stool) consistently, demonstrating reliability.
Quickly adapts when no mice are available by ordering chicken legs and bread instead.
Keeps attentive watch over Lucinnius, anticipating his needs and supporting him discreetly.
Offers to share his bread with other slaves and engages them in conversation, showing social awareness and tact.
Does not intervene or react noticeably when Lucinnius seems troubled or at a social disadvantage.
Shows concentration and compliance with Lucinnius' orders without objection.
Counts out coins to pay Hermas promptly despite Lucinnius's reluctance
Gives Lucinnius a soothing shoulder massage while listening to his troubles
Encourages Lucinnius to face his problems and take action ('You must')
Smiles ruefully at Lucinnius's idealistic plans without explicitly comforting him
Does as he is told without complaint, takes torch discreetly and leaves the room quietly.
Carefully moves out late at night without disturbing his sleeping companions.
Sits down close to Thalia on the roof, showing emotional closeness and physical comfort.
Gives an honest, slightly critical but empathetic description of Lucinnius, acknowledging his misfortune and unpopularity.
Puts an arm around Thalia, a friendly and sincere gesture of warmth and affection.
Puts an arm around Thalia, offering physical comfort.
Engages in intimate and sincere conversation with Thalia, sharing vulnerability about freedom and future.
Reassures Thalia he will never leave her, emphasizing their bond.
Yawns while still kissing her, showing a relaxed, tender moment.
Acknowledges uncertainty about family direction but dismisses negative thoughts.
Smiles at the Man and Woman in the henhouse, acknowledges their meeting place with understanding and kindness.
Speaks politely to the Man in the henhouse and apologizes for disturbing them.
Carries out the task of selecting a chicken for sacrifice without evident cruelty or enjoyment.
Keeps an eye on Lucinnius like a mother watching her child from a distance on its first day at school.
Plays games with other slaves but remains attentive to Lucinnius' progress.
Watches Lucinnius with concern and joins him with a supportive remark after a successful meeting ("You look happier.")
Walks closely with Lucinnius to talk, showing willingness to support and listen.
Keeps a watchful eye on Lucinnius from a distance, indicating attentive awareness and concern.
Plays a game of five-stone and handball while keeping an eye on the office door, showing ability to multitask and remain alert.
Follows Lucinnius closely to talk, showing readiness to engage and support.
Does not intervene directly or encourage Lucinnius despite seeing him looking pathetic and worried in line, suggesting some passivity or hesitance.
Expresses shock and uncertainty about Lucinnius's plan to die, shows concern by trying to understand and respond.
Does not immediately agree or support Lucinnius's wish to die together, says he cannot help.
Is shocked by Lucinnius's plight but does not offer solutions or show understanding; expresses confusion about what to do.
Listens attentively and remains physically close to Lucinnius to talk, indicating presence and concern.
Admits not understanding the situation or how to help, showing lack of clarity and decisiveness.
Shows close friendship and finds comfort in talking to Gallus, Lucinnius's son, reflecting a warm bond and sincerity.
Receives shocking news about being implicated in a conspiracy but does not react with anger or bitterness toward Lucinnius, showing restraint and tolerance.
Initially distances himself from the group choosing death, saying 'You say we... I don't know... what is we? I've done nothing... I know nothing...,' displaying detachment and lack of camaraderie.
Expresses confusion and distance by saying 'I don't know... what is we? I've done nothing... I know nothing...'
Is stunned with shock upon learning he is named a conspirator, showing emotional overwhelm
Manages to speak despite shock and requests to sit down, indicating some self-control
Seeks comfort in a child friend, showing emotional vulnerability but also an attempt to maintain composure
Engages gently with Gallus in a thoughtful conversation about his home and the gods, showing tenderness and expressing care for his children.
Tries to interpret the chicken's behavior optimistically, suggesting maybe there's 'another way' to avoid death and that the chicken might be 'just hungry'.
Offers no help or explanation to Solus when Dalmia questions why she always eats chicken, remaining silent in a moment that could have allowed comfort or honesty.
Interprets the chicken's actions during the omen ritual, attempts to find hopeful meaning against Lucinnius's grim interpretation.
Does not assist Solus when questioned about the repetitive chicken meals, remaining silent and offering no explanation or comfort.
Shares a moment of hope with Lucinnius upon hearing news could be favorable.
Looks at the unpromising visitors and presumably remains composed when they attempt to intimidate.
Closing the door confidently after the meeting, maintaining control of the situation.
Allows visitor to call him roughly, potentially showing lack of assertiveness or failure to immediately defuse tension.
Nods obediently while Visitors instruct him how to kill, does not show discomfort despite being prodded.
Refuses wine from Lucinnius, expresses desire to die free rather than as a slave.
Expresses desire to die a free man and requests a written proclamation so others know he died free
Follows Lucinnius downstairs with an oil lamp, showing trust and support despite fear
Requests a written proclamation to ensure he is recognized as a freed man, showing foresight and awareness of consequences.
Watches keenly over Lucinnius's shoulder while he writes the proclamation, indicating attentiveness and carefulness.
Shows a trickle of fear when Lucinnius picks up a knife, indicating some apprehension but controls it by asking what to do next.
Listens carefully and affirms understanding of Lucinnius's plan, showing readiness to cooperate under pressure.
Sits beside the wounded Lucinnius, speaks gently, helps him lie down, tries to calm him.
Appears to stall or play for time instead of immediately acting on Lucinnius's urgent request.
Sits down calmly beside the injured Lucinnius and speaks gently, coaxing him to lie down and stay still, trying to manage the situation without panic.
Appears to be stalling or playing for time when Lucinnius urges him to act quickly, showing hesitation or indecision in a critical moment.
Hesitates to kill Lucinnius despite being urged to do so; ultimately throws down the knife and flees the scene instead of completing the killing.
Takes Lucinnius's coins and freedom certificate and escapes, showing self-interest and pragmatic survival.
Pauses and changes shoes to Lucinnius's sandals before leaving, suggesting careful planning or respect for circumstances.
Gently shakes Thalia's shoulder to wake her without disturbing others and whispers a quiet invitation to escape together.
Boldly addresses the night watchman to avoid suspicion, protecting their escape.
Keeps the plan vague when asked about the future, showing caution but also consideration for Thalia’s hopes.
Gently shakes Thalia's shoulder, trying not to wake others, showing tact and awareness.
Whispers and acts decisively, quickly initiating escape and urging Thalia to hurry, demonstrating confidence and decisiveness.
Boldly addresses the night watchman to divert suspicion, showing social skills and strategic thinking.
Seeks information about east-bound ships clearly and efficiently, indicating knowledge and purpose.
Strides off with an authoritative nod despite uncertain information, showing confidence.
Answers Thalia's question noncommittally, avoiding detailed explanation, possibly indicating cautiousness or evasiveness.
Approaches crewmen confidently to ask where the captain is and then addresses the captain directly to request passage, showing assertiveness and clear communication.
Claims to have been on a ship before to avoid disappointing Thalia, despite lying.
Wakes Thalia gently and stays close to her while they sleep huddled together.
Draws near to Thalia after noticing her smile, sharing a quiet moment and unspoken communication, showing gentle attentiveness and a shared connection.
Identifies that the ships are lost despite others believing otherwise, showing awareness and skepticism.
Hesitates and expresses disbelief rather than confidently confirming the situation about the ships.
Moves confidently towards Thalia after catching her eye, showing social awareness and emotional intelligence.
Sits absorbed in quiet thought, appearing contemplative rather than taking active initiative.
Grabs the sailor's hat out of the air and arranges it carefully on his head.
Exchanges delicate glances and nonverbal signals of mutual awareness with a woman in the wagon.
Looks at the Priest amusedly, shares his thoughts silently with Beatrice, smiles when she declines to join his walk, and calmly leaves the wagon to walk alone.
Allows the rambling Priest to dominate the conversation but maintains his calm and disengages effectively by walking away.
Smiles as the Priest's voice fades, showing a gentle reaction to others.
Lays himself down by the side of the road and rests, showing no urgent response to the girl's wailing nearby.
Listens carefully to distant sounds and eventually investigates a violent skirmish from afar.
Listens carefully to distant sounds, stands up and investigates what is happening nearby, locates the source of noise and observes the skirmish to understand the situation.
Smiles at Beatrice and shares a playful, mutually accepting attempt at communication despite language barriers.
Allows his foot to touch Beatrice's and notes her not moving away, indicating gentle friendliness.
Does nothing to help the sobbing Girl who wants to go home, and shows greater interest in Beatrice instead.
Knows when to run away from danger quickly and effectively.
Jumps onto a moving wagon confidently and finds safety.
Attempts to communicate with Beatrice despite language barriers, maintaining a positive attitude.
Is unable to comfort or assist the girl who is upset and distressed.
Shows more interest in Beatrice than helping the troubled girl.
Becomes aware of a figure sniffing Beatrice and then follows the figure cautiously downstairs
Creeps cautiously into the kitchen, observes the Priest rummaging food, and relaxes upon recognition
Obeys the Priest without thought when asked to get bread
Acknowledges the Priest saved him in Venice
Obeys the Priest without thought, promptly bringing him bread as requested.
Remains silent when confronted with difficult or emotional topics, showing restraint but possibly passivity.
Shakes his head, catching Beatrice's eye, signaling he will stay despite danger.
Looks with sympathy at the young Squire whose father is injured inside the armor.
Refuses to travel despite pressure, shows resolve and care for others by staying behind.
Looks with sympathy at the squire, indicating emotional awareness and empathy.
Takes time to watch the Squire still kneeling beside his father, quietly stroking the helmet.
Looks at Beatrice and motions for her to follow him outside, moving away from the chaotic scene.
Engages in playful, resourceful communication with Beatrice despite language barrier, sharing stories about home and personal experiences.
Smiles pleased with himself after telling a sad story and scolds Beatrice for laughing.
Admits to being far from home and having been locked up, showing vulnerability and openness.
Uses creative, resourceful methods to communicate with Beatrice despite the language barrier.
Appears slightly confused or unsure as he acknowledges 'I'm not making sense, am I?'
Accepts Beatrice's way of communication and says 'home' in her language, smiles at her caress and shows appreciation for her caring actions
Engages in playful intimacy with Beatrice, suggesting mutual grooming and showing understanding of affectionate teasing
Allows Beatrice to groom him and shows enjoyment, reciprocates by tenderly caring for her, engages in a gentle, intimate interaction.
Tenderly grooms Beatrice’s hair and scalp, showing delight and care even for her fleas, which he wants to keep as a pet.
Engages warmly in conversation by introducing himself and learning Beatrice's name, repeating it softly, showing genuine interest.
Responds positively and affectionately to Beatrice’s requests and signs of discomfort (itchiness), continuing gentle grooming and affectionate kisses.
Makes love to Beatrice quietly in the dark, enjoying the thrill of confounding the Priest
Emerges from pile of clothing, smiles and greets the Priest with a cheeky innocence alongside Beatrice
Makes love quietly in the dark with Beatrice, enjoying the thrill of confounding the Priest.
Emerges from a pile of clothing, sits up and smiles cheekily, mocking the Priest with a false show of innocence.
Is in a cheerful mood, pleased with himself and his success with Beatrice.
Dismisses Priest's advice about Beatrice in a brusque, somewhat rude manner ('Witch my arse. Stop giving me orders.')
Calls the Priest 'a strange fellow' and questions if he is jealous, causing tension and confusion in their friendship.
Calls out to the Priest possibly with an attempt at apology or reconciliation ('I don't understand you.'), showing some emotional openness or sincerity.
Is cheerful and confident about his success with Beatrice, confidently dismisses the Priest's warnings and orders.
Fails to understand the Priest's point and spoils their friendship by provoking him, showing a lack of social tact.
Plans to move on as instructed, indicating he follows through on directions and plans.
Enjoys intimate moments with Beatrice despite language barrier, feeds her cheese from his knife, kisses and caresses her affectionately.
Successfully navigates nonverbal communication and shares intimacy despite language barrier.
Shows awareness of surroundings when they are being watched.
Stops kissing only when Beatrice giggles persistently; looks with concern at the figure by the water.
Acknowledges the dead body openly and ensures they move towards it cautiously with Beatrice.
Helps Beatrice build a protective mound of stones around the dead boy's head.
Realizes the protective stone mound won't keep wolves away and acknowledges the limits of their effort.
Watches passively as Beatrice exchanges shoes with the dead boy without questioning the action.
Smiles approvingly at Beatrice's shoe exchange but does not intervene or reflect on the appropriateness or consequences.
Enjoys and participates in Beatrice's affectionate banter, showing openness and liking her when she talks.
Watches Beatrice's ritual from a safe distance, showing fascination but unease; does not interrupt or mock.
Engages in gentle conversation about the squire's mother, acknowledging shared understanding.
Watches Beatrice sleep with fascination, stays close to her by the fire.
Pays close, admiring attention to Beatrice's hands while she milks the cow, responds distractedly but engaged.
Sniffs her dried flowers and herbs with curiosity and quiet interest.
Follows Beatrice quietly, smiles as she chats with the boatman, despite not understanding.
Expresses uncertainty openly about their direction and tries to communicate his feelings.
Hesitates before following Beatrice inside the house, showing caution and respect for personal boundaries.
Looks at Beatrice in silence when she expresses her wishes and vulnerabilities, suggesting attentiveness and consideration.
Asks about the dead man's cause of death, showing concern and interest in Beatrice's past and feelings.
Keeps his feelings to himself despite understanding Beatrice's feelings and invitation.
His expression lightens in response to Beatrice's warmth and invitation.
Stands surrounded by new family, looks confused and unsure what to do, then politely asks for water to drink and wash.
Stays quietly and does not disrupt family interactions, appears respectful and restrained.
Stands surrounded by a new family, unsure what to do, hesitates before speaking.
Asks for water and a chance to wash using mime, effectively communicating despite language barriers.
Follows the boy to the well without causing trouble, adapting to the situation.
Shyly stands at the door watching the Mother, declines the comfortable chair, insists the Mother sit and even offers to sit on the box despite her objections.
Politely insists the Mother keep the good seat while he takes the less comfortable box, effectively calming her and managing a gentle disagreement.
Stands shyly at the door watching the Mother instead of confidently engaging or stating his purpose.
Retreats to the yard and observes rather than taking direct action or interacting assertively with others.
Joins the Boy in work despite initial clumsiness, shows willingness to participate sincerely.
Acknowledges and shares a brief moment of eye contact with Beatrice while feeling guilty about the chicken sacrifice.
Lets the old Mother serve herself first despite the apparent power play, submitting to her and taking a modest portion.
Opens his heart to Beatrice, sharing his feelings despite difficulty expressing them verbally.
Expresses liking Beatrice honestly and awkwardly, showing sincerity and gentle regard.
Fumbles awkwardly with his bag and struggles with goodbyes, indicating discomfort and lack of ease in social interactions.
Acknowledges the need to leave and keeps a clear objective (getting home to family), showing awareness and responsibility.
Makes an effort to appear relaxed despite internal unhappiness, demonstrating some self-control and social awareness.
Sits down and allows himself to rest when stranded without a boatman, showing appropriate acceptance of situation rather than panic.
Speaks kindly to Andre about a peaceful dream and remembers drinking clear water and eating raspberries, sharing a gentle moment despite the grim situation.
Looks around at the distressed and squalid mass of people on the raft and acknowledges the severity of their predicament with a heartfelt 'God, this is the worst'
Sits against some boxes, speaks calmly to Andre upon awakening on a raft with distressed people around.
Expresses despair about the situation, saying 'God, this is the worst, the worst.'
Attempts to collaborate with Francisco on building a better shelter by offering his possessions and suggesting teamwork.
Fails to persuade Francisco, who reacts with hostility and refuses to cooperate, showing Hector's limited influence in this situation.
Walks briskly towards the trouble with Francisco, actively engaging in the situation of the deserters.
Does not intervene verbally or take a leadership role during the exchange about the deserters' fate, remaining silent and not challenging Dom Paulo's authority.
Avoids volunteering to conduct executions, shows hesitation and lack of courage to accept or refuse
Does not accept or refuse the responsibility to conduct executions; lacks the will or courage to respond when called upon by Dom Paulo.
Compliments Andre's work building the tent.
Tells Andre to sleep by the big fire to keep warm.
Quietly eats his bread alone, shows some guilt.
Thanks Nuno sincerely for the fruit he brings.
Willing to try the fruit after Nuno's warning.
Compliments Andre on his work and thoughtfully suggests Andre sleep by the big fire to keep warm.
Quickly hides his food from Nuno and shows irritation, then politely thanks Nuno for the fruit offering and carefully chooses to try two fruits despite warnings.
Does not immediately respond to Nuno's plea for help about Lopo, indicating hesitation or omission in addressing the situation.
Encourages Nuno to keep strong and look after himself despite the grim situation, offers to share food, tries to comfort Nuno about Lopo.
Shouts cheerily 'Goodnight!' after Nuno stomps away silent and upset, attempts to maintain friendliness.
Encourages Nuno to ration food wisely to stay strong for the difficult times ahead, demonstrating foresight and practical thinking.
Attempts to maintain morale by cheerily saying goodnight after a tense moment, showing emotional intelligence and leadership.
Makes reassuring statements to Nuno to help him cope with traumatic events, indicating social awareness and supportive behavior.
Gives Francisco a small bundle of bread and raisins, explicitly stating it is for Francisco and a woman, showing a desire to share and reconnect.
Shrugs when Francisco looks for an angle, showing sincerity and lack of manipulation.
Calls out that he must speak to her, indicating earnestness and desire to mend relationships.
Gives Francisco a private bundle of bread and raisins intended for another person, showing thoughtfulness and discreet kindness.
Shrugs when questioned about the private act, showing casual confidence and lack of defensiveness.
Seeks to speak to 'her' urgently, indicating initiative and assertiveness.
Is described as simply a lonely man seeking lost friendship, with no ulterior motive, revealing emotional honesty but perhaps social naivety.
Inspects the eggs carefully by cracking them open, shaking them, and assessing their quality before attempting to eat them.
Grunts in annoyance and does not immediately accept poor quality food; shows awareness and discernment.
Does not immediately start eating bad eggs like some others might, indicating caution and some skill in evaluating resources.
Promises Andre to call him by his real name when he remembers, showing effort to respect Andre's wishes.
Smiles at his own insensitivity after telling Andre they're not going to die.
Offers an egg to children to stop making noise, considerate of older and sick camp members.
Shouts across to the musical enthusiast to stop the noise, offering an egg as incentive to think of others.
Smiles at his own insensitivity when telling Andre they are not going to die.
Forgets Andre's real name and hesitates to remember it despite promising to do so.
Drifts off down to the beach while others are selecting goods and organizing resources.
Stops others from bothering the Girl and tells them to help people instead.
Realizes he has hurt the Boy and the Girl, feels like an oaf and expresses regret.
Calls after the Boy to come back, apologizing and saying it was a joke.
Apologizes to the Girl, though she does not respond.
Curses quietly and is angry with himself after realizing he was mean.
Offers one of his bones to Nuno, who he had previously chased away, and apologizes sincerely.
Risks the searing heat to pull at a couple of blackened bones and shares one with Nuno; offers guidance to Nuno on how to suck out the marrow.
Sits with Nuno, recognizes his distress and apologizes for chasing him away earlier; shows social awareness and attempts repair.
Apologizes sincerely for being mean, explains he was upset and not angry at Nuno
Expresses concern about whether Nuno still likes and respects him, values mutual liking and respect
Attempts to cheer Nuno up by offering to introduce him to a boy he knows and playfully nudges him
Passively observes and listens to a meeting without participating
Impulsively approaches Francisco to reconnect, shares a bottle of wine and honeyed fruit despite scarcity, seeks to revive old friendship in a moment of distress.
Notices Ursula is sick and immediately decides to reconnect with Francisco, showing social awareness and quick decision-making in an urgent moment.
Offers to share a precious bottle of wine despite the risks, demonstrating thoughtful gesture and emotional intelligence.
Lingers near Francisco instead of moving on, possibly showing hesitation or lack of clear focus.
Shows understanding of situation and attempts to justify his difficult decisions under pressure, e.g. choosing the raft that was sinking to avoid hurting Ursula.
Appears emotionally overwhelmed and silent when confronted with criticism, indicating limited ability to effectively defend or manage interpersonal conflict.
Expresses vulnerability and self-doubt ('am I so bad?'), revealing a lack of confidence.
Sits beside Nuno and talks earnestly, trying to persuade him to come along, showing concern for Nuno's well-being and future.
Kneels beside the sick Ursula, tries to say goodbye sincerely and expresses remorse for hurting her.
Attempts to explain himself and shows concern by whispering nervously and checking if Ursula is still breathing.
Backs off and says 'Nothing, nothing...' after Ursula reacts indignantly, indicating discomfort with confrontation.
Tries to comfort Ursula despite being shaken, attempts to communicate and apologize sincerely.
Fumbles awkwardly by saying something to offend Ursula and then nervously backtracks, showing lack of social grace.
Watches patiently and waits for Francisco's permission to enter the hut, showing respect and awareness of social boundaries.
Takes initiative to speak privately with Francisco and asks thoughtfully if he can do anything to help, showing care and consideration.
Smiles uncertainly and appears unsure if a joke is being made, indicating some social or emotional uncertainty.
Approaches a delicate subject carefully ('There's no easy way to do it...'), indicating thoughtful communication.
Offers his boots to Francisco despite needing to walk six hundred miles, and pleads poetically about walking home and praying for Francisco's soul
Expresses genuine affection and joy towards Francisco when Francisco offers his boots in return, engaging in friendly, nonsensical small talk
Presents a thoughtful and considerate trade offer for boots, showing awareness of practical needs and future plans.
Uses poetic and persuasive language to successfully convince Francisco to give him the boots.
Engages in nonsensical small talk and fails to catch the joke made by Francisco, indicating some social or perceptual limitation.
Shows concern about missing companions, expresses frustration ('Damn them...') but continues to search thoroughly for clues
Shares discovery of whiskey canteen with Bobby and appears pleased, supporting group morale
Engages in calm conversation with Bobby, showing restraint and composure in anxiety
Scours the campsite and finds a valuable item (Sandy's whiskey).
Expresses frustration and concern ('Damn them...') but quickly acts to assess the situation.
Shows some questioning and curiosity about the environment ('It's too high for Indians?').
No indication of panic despite being in a troubling situation, stays composed with Bobby.
Watches over Bobby while he sleeps calmly despite potential danger nearby (wolf).
Engages cooperatively with Bobby in their work, maintaining discipline and routine during hardship.
Teases Bobby about the chronometer readings in a light-hearted, familiar manner.
Maintains the discipline of work by taking readings and recording data meticulously despite difficult circumstances.
Calmly watches potential danger (wolf) and assesses situation realistically without panic.
Engages in a light-hearted and confident exchange correcting Bobby's time readings, indicating familiarity with their instruments.
Suggests taking the average of two chronometers instead of using just one.
Writes down a time meticulously and speaks pointedly about measurements.
Leads and works methodically with Bobby to build a precise survey point and set up equipment.
Expresses doubt about the plan by asking 'Sure this is a good idea.'
Stops hammering and listens to the unsettling echo, showing awareness of surroundings but no immediate action.
Moves carefully with Bobby and the horse through difficult terrain, maintaining pace despite challenges.
Absurdly greets the Indian with friendliness despite the fear.
Tries to calm Bobby down by telling him 'Don't panic.'
Notices the Indian and turns his head to acknowledge him before the Indian notices them, showing alertness.
Greets the Indian absurdly and reacts silly in a tense situation, indicating social awkwardness and lack of tact.
Fails to keep hold of the horse in their fright, allowing it to run off.
Attempts to calm Bobby down by telling him not to panic after the horse runs away.
Follows Bobby into the forest in a mad race, showing willingness to act but possibly impulsively.
Shares his possessions openly when asked (food, logbooks, letters, candle) and denies having a gun honestly.
Expresses concern about bears and safety in the camp.
Shows no hostility or boastfulness; interacts matter-of-factly and cooperatively with Bobby.
Gives in to reading a letter aloud despite initial reluctance.
Looks up at Bobby after reading, sharing a moment of quiet understanding.
Dismisses Bobby's argument about humor, showing a subtle oversight of Bobby's feelings.
Engages in light-hearted banter with Bobby about smells, sharing a moment of camaraderie.
Offers Bobby a wedge of tobacco he was saving, showing considerate and controlled behavior.
Negotiates playfully with Bobby, turning the tables in their exchange and managing the tense mood effectively.
Shows emotional insight by acknowledging the difficult feelings between him and Bobby and maintaining their friendship.
Insists on talking all night despite Bobby suggesting sleep; takes control of their friendship during an intimate moment.
Reads Bobby’s silence well and initiates discussion gently, apologizes sincerely in an exchange with Bobby.
Offers to share his logbook with Bobby and asks him to sign or write anything in it; tries to honor his son by naming a mountain after him and checks if Bobby is fine with it.
Looks at Bobby with a grey face, acknowledges the danger calmly and chooses to stay close and follow Bobby's lead.
Runs through the women and children during a chaotic chase, unintentionally causing distress and misunderstanding.
States that this isn't really his building and that he just took the call and came over, showing limited ownership or responsibility.
Looks at his watch and keeps track of time accurately.
Checks on the injured lady and speaks clearly for the benefit of others, showing situational awareness and communication skills.
Avoids taking direct responsibility for the floor issue, deflecting to his ex-partner instead of addressing the problem himself.
Expresses concern about the woman's condition, noting she seems in good spirits.
Receives complaints from Mrs. Philippopolis about neglect but does not respond directly to her accusations, retreats and makes calls instead.
Calls Boris urgently, showing frustration but also a desire to resolve the situation quickly, referring to personal commitments (kids).
Threatens legal action to get things moving, shows assertiveness but also self-interest (weekend ruined).
Calls Anna for help, expressing relief and reliance on her support.
Expresses urgency and concern to Anna, explaining the emergency and the need to pick up the kids on time; pleads sincerely for help.
Shows weariness and uncertainty about building maintenance issues, indicating openness and lack of pretense.
Avoids taking immediate responsibility for building maintenance by deferring to Monday, revealing possible procrastination or evasiveness.
Urgently calls Anna for help to get a car and handle an emergency despite personal constraints, showing resourcefulness under pressure.
Acknowledges limitations and delegates checking maintenance records and full building inspection, demonstrating realistic assessment of workload.
Responds wearily and shows uncertainty about technical details like water-resistant paint, indicating some lack of technical knowledge.
Attempts to delay building inspection by asking to postpone it to Monday, possibly underestimating seriousness, which may show poor prioritization.
Calls Leonard to inform him about the accident and potential legal issues promptly, indicating proactive communication.
Calmly manages a domestic accident, checks insurance details promptly, and stays concerned about the injured Mrs. Philippopolis despite her hostility.
Listens patiently to Mrs. Philippopolis's angry and obscene outburst without reacting negatively.
Communicates sincerely with his former wife about the importance of family and his effort to maintain good relations despite difficulties.
Calls promptly to check on insurance certificates after the accident, requests specific information with a clear deadline.
Observes the injured Mrs. Philippopolis and follows paramedics closely, showing attentiveness to the situation.
Manages a difficult conversation with his former wife, showing intention to handle personal and professional matters responsibly and maintain composure.
Considers impulsive action suggested by Mrs. Philippopolis (jumping through the hole), but ultimately restrains himself.
Expresses condolences to George Philippopolis and offers to visit the hospital later and organize flowers.
Declines to visit the hospital immediately despite the son's requests, citing logistical constraints and police backing.
Takes a calm, measured approach to a tense situation by explaining he cannot leave due to official restrictions and offering a specific plan to visit the patient later and organize flowers.
Fails to immediately respond constructively to the Son’s request for hospital assistance or financial help, appearing hesitant and caught off-guard.
Expresses anger towards Boris for using his name irresponsibly, but maintains a calm and forgiving tone after Boris apologizes.
Demanding that Boris remember to use his own name and showing frustration.
Asks clear questions about insurance and legal matters, insists on personal accountability, shows calm reflection after initial anger.
Allows Boris to irresponsibly use his name on documents despite previous warnings, gets angry but does not prevent recurring misuse effectively.
Brightens when he sees Anna, smiles broadly when getting in the car
Expresses readiness to be a father again and talks openly about fixing issues with Boris
Earnest pronouncements about improving relationships and involving kids
Leans over to embrace Anna before she has stopped the car, thanks her sincerely for the car and everything.
Accepts Anna's request to deliver a massive bouquet for a golden wedding despite initial reluctance.

Takes responsibility to deliver the flowers despite initial reluctance, accepts Anna's request to help, plans the route efficiently by asking her to stop at the corner instead of going around the block.
Leans over to embrace Anna before the car stops, showing impatience and slight lack of caution.
Makes an effort to visit his children and reconnect by traveling to New Jersey and arriving on time, showing commitment and care.
Expresses sincere concern about the kids not being happy about the beach house plan and offers to fix it, demonstrating thoughtfulness and genuine desire to accommodate.
Successfully navigates a difficult trip through heavy traffic and arrives on time at his children's house, showing persistence and careful driving.
Calls Leonard about insurance and confirms coverage quickly and confidently, showing preparedness and responsible behavior.
Expresses regret and admits he could have fixed something else for the kids, revealing some lack of foresight in planning the outing.
Expresses fear about taking on responsibility and worries whether he should have spent more time getting to know the children
Nods obediently to Janet and tries to engage with the children despite their cold reception
Attempts to call Anna but stops himself, showing hesitation and worry.
Consults Leonard about the insurance and legal situation, showing effort to manage the problem.
Throws the phone on the passenger seat and sighs, showing signs of stress and possible lack of control.
Puts on a bright front for the kids despite his internal anxiety, showing emotional management and responsibility.
Offers the phone to others to make calls, showing consideration.
Uses nickname 'Tom' despite the person's correction, but then wisely lets it go, showing tolerance and avoiding conflict.
Puts up with Betsy removing items from his cart for a while, tolerating her behavior.
Stands up for his kitchen roll choice but then acknowledges Betsy's point and backs down, showing openness and respect.
Offers the phone to others to make calls, showing consideration and social awareness.
Lets go of the name correction from Thomas instead of insisting, showing social intelligence and tact.
Pushes a cart in Safeway, tries to select items, but is overridden by Betsy multiple times and initially tolerates this without effectively addressing it.
Makes a stand on kitchen roll selection but then quickly backs down when Betsy criticizes and gives logical reasons, showing flexibility and ability to listen.
Fails to anticipate or ask others about their preferences before shopping, leading to conflict and wasted efforts.
Carries sleeping Thomas from the car into the house and puts on exterior lights
Responds to Betsy asking about flowers with 'Don't mention the flowers.'
Watches the kids sleeping next door, showing care and attention
Unlocks the door, puts on exterior lights, carries Thomas inside carefully.
Dismisses Betsy's question about flowers with a vague or curt answer.
Sits bleary-eyed watching an unfocused late-night TV show, appears restless and disengaged.
Watches sleeping kids attentively, showing care and awareness.
Invites Betsy and Thomas to go for a walk and insists on making the outing happen despite initial reluctance.
Offers an umbrella and looks for coats to keep Thomas comfortable in case of rain.
Declines to wear Donald's shoes, feeling uncomfortable with taking on the replacement father's role.
Shows genuine interest and curiosity by noticing and commenting on the kids' height markings on the wall.
Insists on taking a walk despite others' reluctance, prepares for bad weather by looking for coats and shoes, shows awareness of practical needs.
Begins probing about pancakes but drops the topic without understanding Betsy's perspective, showing some social awkwardness or missed insight.
Avoids explaining his feelings about not wanting to wear Donald's shoes, indicating possible emotional complexity but also a reluctance to communicate clearly.
Strides ahead in a show of enthusiasm, calls back to the kids to engage them about the birds.
Speaks quietly to himself showing personal concern (Please don't rain... please...)
Despite the funfair being a sorry sight and the kids' resentment, he tries to make a go of it and invites them to have a ride.
Pulls kitchen roll from his pocket to wipe the wet seats, showing effort and care for the kids' comfort.
Strides ahead in a show of enthusiasm despite awkwardness in big shoes.
Calls back to children trying to engage and understand local changes.
Speaks quietly to himself hoping for good weather.
Makes an effort to salvage a disappointing funfair visit by wiping wet seats with kitchen roll and encouraging the kids to have a ride.
Recognizes the emotional distance between him and his kids and initiates a serious conversation to bridge that gap.
Shows sensitivity by noticing Betsy's patience and courage and is emotionally moved by it.
Offers Betsy a pancake despite her impatience, indicating a polite and considerate nature.
Realizes his children are waiting for him to open up and successfully initiates a serious conversation with them, showing emotional awareness and confidence.
Engages calmly in the difficult conversation, answering their questions thoughtfully and honestly, indicating skill in communication.
Admits to missing his children and feeling conflicted about staying away after the divorce, acknowledging his own struggles.
Expresses some pride when mentioning his jail time as a 'solid excuse' for absence.
Shows appreciation when Thomas wanted to visit him in jail and expresses gratitude.
Describes his business partner from jail as a good man and calls him his friend sincerely.
Expresses that he missed Betsy and Thomas and came to see them.
Shares positive things about his girlfriend Anna and jokes about her in a friendly way with the kids.
Agrees with Betsy that people should talk more, acknowledging the importance of communication.
Got back to work in real estate, found a partner from jail, running a rental business and planning to get into commercial property.
Admits he wasn't in great shape and hesitant to show himself.
Shows openness about personal life, including his girlfriend and plans for the future.
Has to think to remember details about an incident at the gas station.
Reassures Thomas that he is not avoiding him or Betsy despite their concerns.
Comforts Betsy by putting a tentative arm around her shoulder when she is beginning to cry.
Expresses sorrow and apologizes to Betsy for leaving before her swimming test.
Leaves his arm on Betsy's shoulder quietly, showing presence but restraint.
Changes subject to a more positive topic (barbecue) with Thomas, hiding his emotions in a gruff tone.
Corrects Betsy gently about Thomas' name, showing care for his feelings.
Admits he can't face Anna alone and asks Betsy to accompany him, showing vulnerability and trust.
Jokes with Betsy about taking the morning off school, sharing light-hearted intimacy.
Shares tender story about falling in love with Anna and how kind she is, showing openness and affectionate sincerity.
Shares a laugh with Betsy and tries to connect by recalling tender memories about watching her sleep, expressing a feeling of closeness and vulnerability.
Admits to being 'not smart about things like that' and shows openness to Betsy's encouragement to look out for himself, indicating vulnerability and a desire to be better.
Is described as out of his depth with Betsy and shows wonderment and curiosity about her inner self, demonstrating sincere interest and emotional engagement.
Trails after Betsy on the beach, 'hooked,' suggesting a warm, affectionate interest rather than withdrawal or coldness.
Expresses uncertainty and admits to not being smart about emotional or complex interpersonal matters.
Engages thoughtfully and shows emotional sensitivity towards Betsy and the situation, even if out of his depth.
Attempts to connect and understand Betsy despite feeling confused and unsure.

Anxiously watches over children playing near the water, calls them to be safe despite his own lack of confidence, wades out to help with the boat, shares a laugh with the kids after a rope mishap, showing care and lightheartedness.
Calls children back from unsafe boat, tries to keep them safe despite feeling anxious and out of practice.
Wades into water with shoes to help pull boat in, showing willingness to act.
Fails to realize the rope is not attached to the boat, resulting in a useless attempt to pull the boat in.
Acknowledges the mistake with humor and keeps the situation light, maintaining calm.
Laughs with Betsy and Thomas about his difficulty lighting the barbecue, showing self-consciousness and humor.
Serves chicken to others and shares a meal with them, observing them with a warm smile.
Encourages Thomas to remember the simple joys of eating and humming, creating a shared comforting moment.

Reminisces fondly about watching stars with his son, expresses pride in his children’s interests, acknowledges the beauty of the world despite its problems, and shares a warm moment by the fire with family.
Engages playfully in imaginative conversation with Betsy and Thomas, sharing silly ideas and laughing along.
Requests Betsy not to mention flowers tonight, showing some sensitivity to her feelings.
Carefully hoists his two children into higher branches to keep them safe and instructs them to stay quiet and still to avoid danger.
Wakes from a fitful sleep and immediately assesses his surroundings, hardening his resolve before moving stealthily.
Observes a raider approaching the tree from a concealed position, indicating cautious and strategic behavior.
Does not intervene or warn his children when the raider persuades them to come down from the tree, leading to their capture.
Retraces his steps to pick up the piece of rope that once bound him, considering its possible use.
Works carefully and patiently to revive the fire in his cave, showing persistence in physical survival despite emotional shock.
Places the stool at Lucinnius's feet and moves off to get food as requested.
Keeps an eye on Lucinnius while he orders food, showing attentiveness.
Offers to share his bread with the other two slaves, initiating friendly conversation.
Laughs along with others at the suggestion of being sold, but less so than them, indicating restraint and seriousness.
Nods thoughtfully when discussing the downfall of their master, showing silent empathy and reflection.
Trots closer to Lucinnius to aid conversation, showing attentiveness and support.
Responds with short, pragmatic remarks without offering emotional comfort when Lucinnius unburdens concerns.
Provides comfort to Thalia with physical intimacy and matter-of-fact conversation, showing emotional insight and presence.
Admits he does not know the direction to his family, but recognizes the futility of such thoughts after many years.
Expresses realistic understanding that returning home is impossible, grounding the conversation in reality.
Promises loyalty to Thalia and commitment to their relationship with confidence.
Yawns and shows tiredness while trying to reassure Thalia, suggesting some vulnerability or weariness.
Exchanges delicate glances and signals of mutual awareness with the woman in the wagon; shows silent, gentle connection.
Sits quietly observing the tearful girl and the priest's incessant talking, without intervening or comforting.
Carefully probes hair and scalp looking for fleas, attentive to small details.
Establishes connection by introducing himself clearly and engaging gently with Beatrice.
Shifts from a practical task (grooming) to affectionate behavior (kissing), showing adaptability and emotional intelligence.
Appears somewhat distracted as grooming becomes less focused, possibly losing some task-specific focus.
Watches Beatrice's ceremony from a safe distance, showing awareness and caution.
Engages in affectionate banter without understanding fully but maintains positive social interaction.
Suggests leaving the scene because they have been there too long, indicating situational awareness.
Does not question or challenge the magical ceremony he observes, suggests a lack of deeper understanding.
Works with the others to row the raft to shore despite the difficulty.
Overpowers Ursula and wrestles her load from her grasp despite her refusal; acts angrily.
Offers cloth and carpet to Francisco to help build a better shelter, attempting to collaborate and heal past wounds.
Persists courteously despite Francisco's rejection, does not respond with anger or bitterness.
Expresses hatred for people having to die.
Attempts to ingratiate himself with Francisco, hoping to be friendly.
Advocates for friendship rather than conflict.
Shares the experience of eating the turtle eggs with others at the camp, discusses the eggs with Andre in a straightforward manner.
Expresses annoyance quietly and observes the spoiled eggs without complaining loudly or blaming anyone.
Quickly searches through discarded boxes to find useful materials, pulls out nails and pockets them.
Cautiously climbs a dune to survey the area before being seen, showing awareness of surroundings.
When caught watching the young boy and girl, initially ducks down but then chooses to confront them directly and assertively.
Regains his natural self-confidence after a difficult moment.
Seeks reassurance from Nuno and addresses relationship issues openly and respectfully.
Attempts multiple approaches to win Nuno over despite limited success.
Sits silently and listens during a meeting, attentively observing the mood shifts.
Brought sweets for Ursula, showing thoughtfulness.
Expresses feeling of always being guilty and sorry, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Silent after being told he took away Ursula's pride, possibly reflecting on his mistakes.
Argues about needing to get on the same raft as Ursula, showing concern and defense rather than avoidance.
Asks Francisco for understanding (please), demonstrating emotional openness.
Sits beside Nuno and talks earnestly, trying to persuade him to come along despite Nuno's refusal.
Helping Nuno to carry his mother in a litter during a difficult journey.
Looking for Francisco to see 'her' before leaving, showing concern.
Helping Nuno carry his mother in a litter during the difficult trek.
Looking for Francisco to see a woman before departure, showing initiative and responsibility.
Takes Francisco aside to talk alone, offers help or a message to him, smiles uncertainly trying to connect, shows concern.
Engages in light teasing with Bobby about being unscientific.
Turns around, surprised by Bobby singing loudly and frightening himself.
Works quietly and methodically with Bobby to build the cairn together.
Acknowledges the injured Mrs. Philippopolis and asks how she is feeling, showing concern despite the stressful situation.
Shifts responsibility of building issues to his ex-partner when confronted by Mrs. Philippopolis, avoiding direct accountability.
Immediately takes initiative to make calls to resolve the building situation.
Shows frustration and urgency about the situation and his personal plans.
Appears confused about the building not being his responsibility and questions why he was called.
Calmly accepts help from Anna and shows gratitude for it, indicating readiness to take on new responsibilities.
Expresses confidence about fixing problems with Boris and taking control of his life, showing determination and a plan.
Mentions optimistic plans about family arrangements and living situation, showing forward thinking and realistic goal-setting.
Compares nervousness to being executed but does not let it disable him, indicating emotional resilience.
Gets scared about the responsibility he has taken on and doubts whether he should have prepared more before meeting the children.
Listens to Janet’s encouragement and proceeds to take the children for the weekend despite reservations.
Nods obediently to Janet, showing compliance rather than confident leadership.
Moves quietly out of the room after hearing Betsy's sobs, showing sensitivity to her distress.
Scrambles eggs for the children and asks if they want some, attempting to take care of them.
Probes gently about how many eggs the children can have, showing consideration for their needs.
Corrects Betsy gently when she calls Thomas 'Tom' because Thomas doesn't like it, showing awareness and sensitivity to others' preferences.
Expresses vulnerability about facing Anna alone but skillfully involves Betsy to support him, demonstrating emotional intelligence and social skill.
Engages Betsy warmly and playfully, easing tension about her taking time off school with a lighthearted joke, indicating confidence and the ability to manage interpersonal dynamics.

Shows emotional insight by recalling how he fell in love with Anna from an unusual moment, and candidly shares this story with Betsy, reflecting self-awareness but also some naivety in following a woman after jail.
Fails to light the barbecue despite multiple attempts, becomes self-conscious about his inability.
Turns the meat on the barbecue successfully and serves chicken to others, showing capability in cooking once the fire is established.
Recalls and shares his past skills and habits confidently, demonstrating insight and awareness of his own competence.
Confuses Mercury with Jupiter but quickly acknowledges his son's correction and expresses genuine interest in his children's projects.
Shows pride and encourages his children’s engagement with important scientific ideas despite his own lack of detailed knowledge.
Forgets some past memories (does not recall details about star-gazing with his son).
